cab.content:
THIS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OF HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S GOYERNMENT
Printed for the War Cabinet. October 1939.
SECRET. Copy No. 3
W.M. (39)
64th Conclusions.
TO BE KEPT UNDER LOCK AND KEY.
It is requested that special care may be taken to ensure the secrecy of this document.
WAR CABINET 64 (39).
CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the War Cabinet held at 10 Downing Street, S. W. 1, on Sunday, October 29, 1939, at 12 noon.
Present
The Right Hon. Sir John Simon, K.C., M.P., Chancellor of the Exchequer (in the Chair).
The Right Hon. Winston S. Churchill, M.P., First Lord of the Admiralty.
The Right Hon. Sir Kingsley Wood, M.P., Secretary of State for Air.
The following were also present:
Air Vice-Marshal R. E. C. Pierse, Deputy Chief of the Air Staff.
Rear-Admiral T. S. V. Phillips, Deputy Chief of Naval Staff.
Major-General H. R. S. Massy, Deputy Chief of the Imperial General Staff.
Secretariat. Sir Edward Bridges. Colonel L. C. Hollis, R.M. Lieutenant-Colonel E. I. C. Jacob, R.E.
[20238J
WAR CABINET 64 (39).
Contents.
Minute
No. Subject. Page.
1 Air Operations......^................ 539
2 Naval Operations .................. 539
3 Military Operations.................. 539
4 Possibility of sea-borne and air-borne land attack on
Great Britain
351
539
W.M. 64 (30).
Air Operations. 1. The Secretary of State for Air said that it was clear that (Previous only one aircraft had been over the Forth the day before, and it had
Eeference: been shot down.
W.M. (39) 63rd A message sent out by the German reconnaissance aircraft Conclusions, which had flown over the Orkneys had been intercepted. Its report Minute 1.) "nothing here, am returning" indicated clearly that the
Germans were looking for the Fleet.
An aircraft had driven off a submarine which had been in the
act of attacking a merchant ship.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.
5$
Naval Operations.
(Previous Eeference: W.M. (39) 63rd Conclusions, Minute 2.)
Military Operations.
(Previous Eeference: W.M. (39) 63rd Conclusions, Minute 4.)
2. The First Lord of the Admiralty said that a lookout was being kept for the City of Flint.
A British ship of 7,900 tons had been torpedoed in convoy. It was afloat, and it was hoped to bring it into port. The submarine was being hunted.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.
3. The Deputy Chief of the Imperial General Staff said that there was no change to report; nor was there any confirmation of the reported movement and concentration in the North-West of Germany.
The Deputy Chief of Naval Staff said that reports had been received of a concentration of shipping in the Elbe of the type which would be used in an attack on Holland.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statements.
Possibility of 4. The First Lord of the A dmiralty said that action was
sea-borne and proceeding to give effect to the naval dispositions agreed upon at
air-borne land the meeting of the War Cabinet referred to in the margin,
attack on Great There was also some discussion on the measures which should
Britain. be taken on land to meet the possibility of attack by parachutists,
(Previous which is recorded in the Secretary's Standard File of War Cabinet
Eeference: Conclusions.
W.M. (39) 63rd The War Cabinet took note of the above statement and
Conclusions, discussion. Minute 5.)
Richmond Terrace, S. W. 1, October 29, 1939.
